content.title: Matateljén, trendy rustic

introduction.small: In the green and peaceful suburb of Gamla Enskede, Matateljén draws inspiration from the neighbourhood's quaint atmosphere and offers healthy, local eating.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Matateljén, trendy rustic

paragraphs.text:
In sync with Gamla Enskede, the peaceful southern suburb of Stockholm and first Swedish “garden city” where the restaurant took hold, Matateljén conveys a warm and cosy atmosphere in a rustic setting. The seasonal menu changes daily, showcasing a variety of fresh products, as well as light and healthy dishes, often suitable for vegetarians.

Servings are voluntarily small, in a sharing and tasting spirit: the hard choice is no more, as you can order several dishes to your liking and share them with the rest of your dining party. Here, cooking is fine-tuned and flavours are innovative, in keeping with an inspiring culinary experience. The menu does not display the exact nature of each dish, but rather a succession of ingredients – transparency is paramount – like “rabbit, cheddar and green hot peppers”, “pesto salsify, pecorino cheese and marinated onions” or “agnolotti (stuffed pasta) alla ricotta, with zamorano (Spanish goat cheese), artichokes and sage”. Dive deeper into the location's atmosphere and explore backstage. For that, book early and ask for a table set in the very middle of the open kitchen!

Matateljén
Stora Gungans Väg 7
122 62 Enskede

+46 (0)8 409 198 10

matateljen.se

Menu: around 225 SEK

content.title: L'Avventura, Italian gastronomy in a movie decor

introduction.small: Set in a 1920s movie theatre in Stockholm, L'Avventura is a fascinating restaurant with an exceptional setting for its delicious and attentive Italian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Avventura, Italian gastronomy in a movie decor

paragraphs.text:
Stucco mouldings, high ceilings, wall paintings that hark back to the murals of Pompei, red carpet on the stairs… Everything would lead you to believe you are enjoying a night at the theatre. Well, you are not far off, for this is the exceptional setting chosen by L'Avventura, an Italian restaurant of the Vasastan residential district in Stockholm.

Amid this former movie theatre built in the 1920s, appetizing Mediterranean scents elevate from the kitchen, and find their way around olive trees and right to you, for an experience taking right into Giuseppe Tornatore's Cinema Paradiso. In this unique atmosphere, choose among the menu's various Italian specialities, reworked in gastronomic fashion: truffle, cep and parmesan pappardelle, the melanzane – an oven-baked eggplant covered in tomato sauce, mozzarella, provolone and basil – or the whole roast chicken as a family dish, basted with paprika and tomatoes.

However, no pizzas are to be found here – they have been outlawed from the menu in favour of other dishes inspired by various Italian regions. The décor, at once historical and overwhelming, and the inspired Italian menu make L'Avventura a must in the Swedish capital. Bookings are made way in advance, so act fast!

L'Avventura
Sveavägen 77
113 50 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 519 422 74

https://lavventura.se/en

Menu: around 315 SEK

content.title: Explore the daily life of Vikings

introduction.small: Go back a thousand years at the Viking Museum, on Djurgårdsvägen island, and follow the footsteps of this Nordic people, far from bloody myths.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the daily life of Vikings

paragraphs.text:
With their rites, traditions and historic bearings that linger on today, Vikings are ever fascinating. Various films, books and even video games have drawn from the folklore of this Nordic people, often described as barbaric warriors. But was that really the case? Forget about violence, horned helmets and bearded faces. The Viking Museum (also known as Vikingaliv, the “Viking life”) breaks the myth and gives history its legitimate place. With an interactive walkthrough that is bound to captivate both kids and lovers and Ragnar Lodbrok (the hero of the famous TV show Vikings), this small museum located on the Djurgårdsvägen island will reveal detailed chronicles with no bias.

There, you will meet an authentic Viking warrior, or rather his full-size reproduction called “Leifur”. Using DNA found on bones in the Sigtuna archaeological camp site (Sweden's oldest town, about 50 km north of Stockholm), the mannequin is the “incarnation” of a true Viking. However, data studies found that Leifur was a vegetarian, far from the commonplace image of Nordic people during the iron age! Highlight of your visit, you can travel back to the end of the first millennium of our times through the fictitious story of Ragnfrid, Viking woman whose life is told with a sound and light show.

The Viking Museum
Djurgårdsvägen 48
115 21 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 400 229 90

https://thevikingmuseum.com/en/

content.title: Wine tastings at Folii

introduction.small: In the Södermalm neighbourhood, where Stockholm's new gastronomic scene is developing, the Folii bar offers an attractive wine selection.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wine tastings at Folii

paragraphs.text:
In the background, a turntable plays some jazz classics. Beatrice Becher conceived this wine bar from start to finish and it is the talk of the town. With books on the shelves, chic-industrial lighting, scattered candles and standards of music for the atmosphere, the young lady managed to create an inviting and personal universe, where everybody feels right at home.
A wine specialist who won awards in Sweden and Norway, she updates her selection on a daily basis, and pairs them with a few fresh snacks. By the bottle, the glass or even half-glass (to be enjoyed in moderation), all combinations are possible, with precisely and artfully selected wines from France, Italy and Chile among others. Folii does not take reservations and it is therefore recommended to arrive early as the room is rapidly full!

Folii
Erstagatan 21
116 36 Stockholm

https://folii.se/en/welcome-to-fooli/

Menu: glass of wine from 130 SEK

content.title: Hotel Skeppsholmen, Stockholm's island oasis

introduction.small: Recharge your batteries at Skeppsholmen, a splendid hotel hidden among the island's foliage, in the centre of Stockholm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Skeppsholmen, Stockholm's island oasis

paragraphs.text:
On a peaceful island in the heart of the capital, two beautiful buildings constructed at the dawn of the 18th century house a design gem. Very close to the Moderna Museum and a stone's throw away from the old city, Hotel Skeppsholmen offers 78 gorgeous rooms that bring together old-world charm with modern and refined decor. Wherever you are in this unique establishment, you will enjoy astounding views of the gardens or waves. As for the bright warm restaurant, it offers a creative menu based on seasonal products that draws its inspiration from Swedish culinary tradition.
Once you have explored Stockholm's most beautiful sites near the hotel, enjoy its tranquil surroundings for a jog in the park or play tennis on the clay court. Experienced sailor or eager to discover the pleasures of a boat trip, take the time for a ride on the Baltic or a fishing expedition.

Hotel Skeppsholmen
Gröna gången 1
Box 1616
111 86 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 407 23 00

https://hotelskeppsholmen.se/en/

Rooms: from 1,483 SEK

content.title: Island escape to Finnhamn

introduction.small: A stone's throw away from Stockholm, head over to discover the islands during an idyllic stop, where time has no hold.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Island escape to Finnhamn

paragraphs.text:
At the edge of Stockholm, you will find a natural wonder. At the confluence of Lake Mälaren and the Baltic Sea lies an archipelago formed by glaciers, bringing together 25,000 islands, islets and skerries over nearly 50 km.
Two hours and fifty minutes away from the capital by ferry boat, a northern paradise that owes its name to the Finnish boats that once stopped there to refuel stretches over wild and authentic landscapes. Finnhamn is famous for its deep black waters and marshes, as well as its lush flora of pines, oaks and birches.
Make a stop in one of its enchanting coves such as well-named Paradise Bay, where boaters anchor in the summer. On the programme, you will be spoilt for choice: rowing excursion, fishing trip or sauna session followed by a dip in the icy waters and benefactors of this preserved and pedestrian island, outside of time.

https://www.visitstockholm.com/stockholm-archipelago/finnhamn/

content.title: Learn about the Nobel Prizes

introduction.small: Do you really know everything about the Nobel Prize? The museum carrying the same name traces its history back to 1901 and that of Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Learn about the Nobel Prizes

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Gamla Stan Island – the old city of Stockholm, the Nobel Prize Museum is housed in one of the most beautiful buildings in the city, just next to the Storkyrkan Church and Stortorget Square.
Alfred Nobel vowed in his will that part of his fortune be allocated each year to reward the most innovative scientists in the fields of chemistry, physics, medicine, literature and peace. Since 1901, more than 900 luminaries have won the famous Nobel Prize.
Through your visit, discover the laureates Pierre and Marie Curie as well as their daughter Irène, Nelson Mandela and, more recently, Malala Yousafzaï. You will learn everything about the award ceremony that takes place every year on the 10th of December in the main Blue Hall of Stockholm's City Hall and leave with all the secrets of the Nobel Prizes.

Nobel Museum (Nobelmuseet)
Stortorget 2
Gamla stan
103 16 Stockholm
+46 (0)8 534 818 00

https://nobelprizemuseum.se/en/

content.title: At the heart of Swedish culture at Nordiska Museet

introduction.small: More than 500 years of Swedish history are available to you in a building worthy of a fairy tale.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At the heart of Swedish culture at Nordiska Museet

paragraphs.text:
On the island of Djurgården, you cannot miss the impressive Nordic Museum -
"Nordiska Museet" in Swedish. The immense Renaissance-style building seems to have always been there, but it only dates back to 1907. Meanwhile, the collection has existed since 1873, when Artur Hazelius took the initiative to create a museum about popular culture and traditions.
The largest monument of its kind in Sweden, the Nordiska brings together over 500 years of the country's history within its walls. Among the permanent exhibitions, do not miss those on past and present homes, jewellery, design and fashion. Another, particularly interesting, is entirely devoted to the Sami, the only indigenous Swedish people still living in Lapland, which has had to adapt to the world around them.
The three floors of Nordiska Museet are organised around an enormous hall in the centre of which stands a wooden statue of King Gustav I. On the ground floor, you will find a souvenir shop, a restaurant serving local specialities, as well as the reconstruction of a full-size 1940s Swedish apartment.

Nordic Museum (Nordiska Museet)
Djurgårdsvägen 6-16
115 93 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 519 546 00

https://www.nordiskamuseet.se/en

content.title: Rosendal Trädgård, a country corner in Stockholm

introduction.small: Stockholm, world-renowned for its architecture and design, is home to a treasure trove of gardens where you can stroll in all seasons, just like a real Swede.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rosendal Trädgård, a country corner in Stockholm

paragraphs.text:
Created at the beginning of the 19th century by Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte, a former Marshal of Napoleon who became King of Sweden in 1818 under the name of Karl XIV Johan, the gardens of Rosendal will delight nature lovers. If part of the royal park was transformed into an English garden by King Johan, Queen Josefina, a gardening lover, worked to install the first plantations and greenhouses where today a rose garden, an organic vegetable garden, vines, field flowers and aromatic plants flourish.

The estate has a functioning farm and a charming café where you can enjoy freshly harvested produce. Stop at the artisanal bakery where the smell of bread baked on a wood fire will whet your appetite. To keep a souvenir of your visit, stop by the horticultural shop where seedlings, potted plants and fresh flowers await.

On foot or by bike, you will enjoy exploring the paths of this little corner of paradise, just a few minutes from downtown.

Rosendal Garden (Rosendal Trädgård)
Rosendalsterrassen 12
115 21 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 545 812 70

https://www.rosendalstradgard.se/in-english/

content.title: Gastrologik: New Nordic Cuisine

introduction.small: Jacob Holstrom is the leader of a new generation of young Swedish chefs who are revisiting their roots and giving them a contemporary update.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gastrologik: New Nordic Cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Jacob Holstrom's cooking is a Nordic experience that you must try at least once in your life if you are passing through Stockholm. The Nordic tone is set as soon as you enter this starred restaurant: everything is in white, natural wood, while flavours are on par. Nordic, indeed.

Time to explore the menu, which changes daily. Today, the starter is forest-flavoured potato chips, followed by chicken meringue and apple, mushrooms with toasted yeast cream, smoked spring mackerel with green asparagus, cucumber granita and spruce shoots, and, finally, a crunchy oatmeal with honey. Like little music notes in a well-written score, each dish is present but different, scented with the forest undergrowth, and textured with the crunchiness of grain. It is impossible to be more natural.

Gastrologik
Artillerigatan 14
114 51 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 662 30 60

https://gastrologik.com/

Menu: around 1,800 SEK

content.title: Meatballs for the People: the kingdom of meatballs

introduction.small: You only eat meatballs here, the most rustic and classic dish in Swedish cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meatballs for the People: the kingdom of meatballs

paragraphs.text:
In Swedish, they are called Köttbullar. When you think of meatballs, you often think of the ones your mother made.

But these are made with as much love and come in a multitude of varieties. They differ according to the seasons, but the menu always displays fourteen different recipes. You may try some with dill, while others are made of lamb with fennel seeds or pork with spices. You will also find salmon, trout, or herring meatballs, and, finally, for vegetarians, vegetable 'meatballs'. You finally choose the accompaniment, with or without cranberries, mustard sauce, potato pancake, or pickled cucumber. You can eat them on the spot or, like many Stockholmers, as a takeaway lunch.

Finally, do you know the secret of a good meatball filling? The crumbs, which are one of its basic ingredients, should always be soaked in milk.

Meatballs for the People
Nytorgsgåtan 30
116 40 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 466 60 99

www.meatball.se/en-se

Menu: around 254 SEK

content.title: Grand Hôtel, the Nobel residence

introduction.small: This is truly royal! And, that's not just a play on words, since this hotel is the ‘official' palace of Stockholm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand Hôtel, the Nobel residence

paragraphs.text:
Royal families, heads of state on official visits, and Nobel laureates and their families always stay here. Built in the late 19th-century, the Grand Hotel has retained the spirit of classic luxury, where every detail counts, without grandstanding.

In a city that is now visited for its flagship design, the Grand Hôtel has managed to keep its cachet. The bar is the meeting-place for Stockholmers, and is called Cadier, as in Jean-François Cadier, the French founder of the hotel.

Its restaurant, the kind where major contracts are being made, is one of the best in the capital, thanks to its chef, Mathias Dahlgren. The Nordic spa is famous for its Swedish massages and traditional care inspired by Chinese medicine. As for the rooms, always book those with views of the harbour. Watch the boats come and go, and imagine that tomorrow you are leaving on a long ocean crossing…

Grand Hôtel
Södra Blasieholmshamnen 8
Box 164 24
103 27 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 679 35 00

https://www.grandhotel.se/en

Rooms: from 2,884 SEK

content.title: Fotografiska: the Scandinavian reference point for contemporary photography

introduction.small: By the Baltic Sea, where ferry boats dance around, this museum is dedicated to the most beautiful works in contemporary photography.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fotografiska: the Scandinavian reference point for contemporary photography

paragraphs.text:
The Swedes are cultural agitators. There is no way they would allow themselves to be left out of any artistic movements going on in the world.

Opened in 2010, Fotografiska is now a Scandinavian institution in terms of images and it is the largest photography museum in the world. Black-and-white landscapes, conceptual works, fashion shots… Four or five major exhibitions are presented each year: an Annie Leibovitz retrospective, a tribute to Sebastião Salgado, a close-up look at Martin Schoeller and about 20 thematic or monographic shows. The museum has housed more than 200 exhibitions over a decade. With high-quality large prints and handsome framing, the Fotografiska is well regarded by artists and amateurs alike.

As it remains open till 11:00 p.m., Stockholmers dine early and come after to enjoy the view of the Baltic and the island of Skeppsholmen as the sun sets.

Fotografiska
Stadsgärdshamnen 22
116 45 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 509 005 00

https://www.fotografiska.com/

content.title: Grandpa: best in design, fashion, and accessories

introduction.small: A relaxed atmosphere and recycled materials are the hallmarks of this showcase of Swedish style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grandpa: best in design, fashion, and accessories

paragraphs.text:
What differentiates a regular concept store from this particular one? The answer is: the personality of their creators, of course.

Grandpa does not showcase clothes, objects, and accessories in regular displays, but on tables, shelves, and in cabinets, so that everyone feels at home. It cultivates an intimate spirit of vintage and nature. The shop is unisex, so women may fall for a man's sweater for instance. They are available in comfortable wool and almost indestructible cashmeres. All jackets, t-shirts, and shirts are locally made out of organic fabrics.

Among the top 10 brands selected: Neuw and Hope flared jeans, Uniforms for the Dedicated jackets, and Sätila wool socks and beanies. At night, Grandpa turns into a trendy hotspot where the local youth gather to the sound of live music and dance to beats of DJ sets.

Grandpa
Södermannagatan 28
116 40 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 643 60 80

https://www.grandpastore.com/en/store-sodermannagatan

content.title: In Stockholm, the bicycle is king

introduction.small: Forget taxis, cars, and the subway! In Stockholm, you cycle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In Stockholm, the bicycle is king

paragraphs.text:
The bicycle is the fastest and most practical means of transport for getting around in the city. You can go easily from one island to another, and thoroughly enjoy the charm of the different neighbourhoods.

With 760 km of cycle paths, you can pedal away, far from car exhaust. As the city struggles to become carbon neutral, everyone is contributing by riding bikes! The paths are marked, protected, well lit; and listed on maps. You cannot go wrong or get lost! From April 1 to October 31, more than 1,000 'Stockholm City Bikes' are parked in the city. To rent one, buy a magnetic card at the tourist office. It is valid for three days and recharges online.

As well, almost all hotels make bikes or magnetic cards available to their guests. More cautious guests can also rent helmets.

www.citybikes.se/en/

content.title: Ekstedt: the cuisine of a man of fire

introduction.small: Low temperatures and convection heat-induction stoves have no place here. There's just a wood fire, embers, and ashes for cooking that goes back to the basics.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ekstedt: the cuisine of a man of fire

paragraphs.text:
If you live outside Stockholm, you cannot know Ekstedt Mat. He is the star of Niklas'Mat, the cult television cooking show. The least one can say is that though he has hosted guest chefs like Gordon Ramsay and, in his time, Joël Robuchon, they have had no influence on his own restaurant.

The setting is almost like a lumberjack's cabin. At the stove are bearded and tattooed men listening to Radiohead. There are no hot plates or gas burners here. Meat and fish are cooked over a wood fire, in ashes, or smoked.

In developing his recipes, the chef immersed himself in Swedish working-class culture, going back to 17th-century recipes like the slow-cooked lamb shanks served with artichokes and yellow beetroots, or the smoked turbot with leafy greens. Surprising? Yes, and excellent too. One word of warning: avoid the sourdough bread and the freshly churned, creamy butter they are too addictive!

Ekstedt
Humlegårdsgatan 17
114 46 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 611 12 10

https://ekstedt.nu

Menu: from 980 SEK

content.title: The Museum of Modern Art on the Island of Statues

introduction.small: When you arrive on the island of Skeppsholmen, you are greeted by birds, the famous ‘nanas' of Niki de Saint Phalle, and the constructions of Jean Tinguely and Alexander Calder.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Museum of Modern Art on the Island of Statues

paragraphs.text:
Everything is quiet here. There are no cars, just bikes, sailboats, and paintings. A lot of paintings ...

Because of the modern art museum that has been in a building that looks like a boathouse since 1958.Do not be fooled by appearances. This is the most interesting collection in northern Europe. Its different directors have all bequeathed their tastes and their bias to what is now an internationally renowned museum. The first, Ponthus Hultén, was a knowledgeable collector. He donated more than 700 works, including sculptures by Niki de Saint Phalle, Jean Tinguely, and Alexander Calder, which are in the garden. Today, more than 130,000 works (including about 100,000 photographs, making it one of the largest collections in the world) have taken hold on the island.

After highlighting Nordic Art, French Modernism and American creations from the 1950s and 1960s, the museum has taken a keen interest on contemporary women artists. The museum's success launched the creation of a new branch, which opened in 2009 in Malmö, northern Denmark.

Stockholm Museum of Modern Art (Moderna Museet)
Skeppsholmen
111 49 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 5202 3500

https://www.modernamuseet.se/stockholm/en/

content.title: Oaxen Slip: seafood's return

introduction.small: A seafood brasserie, specialising in freshly caught fish.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oaxen Slip: seafood's return

paragraphs.text:
Nothing is more pleasant than to lunch or, especially, have dinner in this brasserie on Beckholmen island. Amidst ships and shipyards, you realise that Stockholm is a port, and Sweden, a country of sailors.

Oaxen Slip serves frankly Scandinavian cuisine. The kitchen only prepares fish and shellfish from the Baltic Sea. Start with some delicious norrøna herring in brown butter with its warm tuber salad, minced egg, marinated yellow beetroot and nuts. Then, order some fried fish with raw greens, root vegetables, remoulade dressing and potatoes, or the catch of the day simply sprinkled with lemon juice for the best experience in freshness. The restaurant does not forget meat lovers, who will revel in the fried pork cheeks, moderately spicy and served with a garlic and coriander mayo. Unless you would rather choose the duck confit with blackcurrants.

A perfect example of Nordic bistro, this address situated by the water is a must-go-to during any Stockholm stay.

Oaxen Slip
Beckholmsvågen 26
115 21 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 551 531 05

https://oaxen.com/en/bistro-slip/

Menu: around 325 SEK

content.title: Östermaln Saluhall: a mouth-watering market

introduction.small: Herring, lobsters, salmon… Shop for your next meal and have lunch here, where the ambience is as good as the traditional Swedish dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Östermaln Saluhall: a mouth-watering market

paragraphs.text:
It is impossible not to come back from this market without pickled herring, black bread, and a bottle of aquavit – barley or potato liquor scented with various herbs – for an improvised Swedish dinner.

For gourmet shopping, head for the Östermaln covered market! There are many small markets and supermarkets in Stockholm. They are almost all organic and are frequented daily by Stockholmers. But, here, you are in the temple of Swedish cuisine. For the smoked reindeer and elk salami, go to Andersson Fagel & Vilt. The best place for marinated salmon, whitefish eggs, and Baltic oysters is Lisa. Of course, there are others, as well…

Do not hesitate to stop and savour a hot dog and a strong beer at one of the small carts or cafés that cultivate the 'street-food' spirit. You can also make a real meal of it and have reindeer steak with cranberries and mashed potatoes.

Östermalms Saluhall
Östermalmstorg
114 39 Stockholm

https://en.ostermalmshallen.se

content.title: Story Hotel Riddargatan, a place to see and be seen in

introduction.small: The trendiest hotel in Stockholm!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Story Hotel Riddargatan, a place to see and be seen in

paragraphs.text:
Story Hotel Riddargatan's fine and continuing reputation is due to its unique blend of elegance and relaxation, both chic and recycled, reflecting the current taste of Stockholmers. In the Östermalm neighbourhood, centre of the glamourous life in the Swedish capital, the hotel took up former apartments that have been entirely renovated. Its Asian restaurant, Ling Long, also found a home in what used to be a garage, while the lobby was a former barber shop.

Wallpaper and original floors are the background for eclectic, mismatched furniture. Its unfinished-looking, underground chic is emphasised by the hotel's artworks and even its sign. The ancient font pays homage to this trendy neighbourhood's printing and publishing past.

Beyond its looks, the Story Hotel Riddargatan's level of service is exemplary, making the address a local reference for high-end hospitality.

Story Hotel Riddargatan
Riddargatan 6
114 35 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 545 039 40

https://storyhotels.com/riddargatan/

Rooms: from 870 SEK

content.title: The Skansen Museum: a village back in time

introduction.small: This outdoor museum traces five centuries of housing history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Skansen Museum: a village back in time

paragraphs.text:
Do you remember M. Night Shyamalan's movie, The Village? If you leave aside the plot, you are entering the fantasy world of the most visited open-air museum in the world, founded by Arthur Azelius. At the end of the 19th century, when Sweden began industrialising, this ethnologist had the idea of presenting, in three dimensions, scenes of Swedish rural life, in order to preserve their memory. These early enactments represented Sweden at the Paris World Exhibition in 1873, and led to Azelius starting an ethnological movement. Over the years, the museum has been expanded into a real village with more than 150 buildings. There are traditional farmhouses, mansions, and Sami tents. The buildings are authentic they are dismantled brick by brick, and board by board, then faithfully reassembled. Though the result could be folkloric, here, as is usual for Sweden, everything is refined.

Skansen also includes a Scandinavian zoo with owls, otters, deer, and elk for the delight of all.

Skansen Museum
Djurgårdsslätten 49-51
115 21 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 442 80 00

https://www.skansen.se/en/

content.title: Stallmästaregarden: the country in the city

introduction.small: At the heart of the Royal Park, surrounded by nature, this hotel cultivates a bucolic atmosphere, mere minutes from downtown.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stallmästaregarden: the country in the city

paragraphs.text:
Queen Christina loved to stay here in the 17th century. As with all charming Swedish houses, Stallmästaregården plays off its Gustavian style, tells a story, while breaking with Nordic classicism via added contemporary touches.

In the dining room, the furniture is dominated by the 1950s and, in the living room, the lamps are by the British designer Tom Dixon. The Swedes are masters in the art of mixing eras. In Stockholm, eclecticism has become the contemporary Swedish signature. At this 100% city hotel, enjoy summer evenings that do not seem to end in the hotel garden, and experience the slightly surreal atmosphere of suspension, which is so typical of Swedish summers.

Amid a natural setting and overlooking the Brunnsviken bay, the comfortable rooms and their trendy 'raw' kitchen design make you feel like you are in a bubble outside of time.

Hotel Stallmästaregården
Norrtull
113 47 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 610 13 00

https://stallmastaregarden.se/en/

Rooms: from 1,526 SEK

content.title: ABBA The Museum: visit Agnetha, Björn, Benny and Anni-Frid

introduction.small: Since 2013, the legendary 1970s pop band have had their own museum. Tour it to the beat of one of their hits. Mamma mia!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ABBA The Museum: visit Agnetha, Björn, Benny and Anni-Frid

paragraphs.text:
Plunge into the frankly entertaining and not at all nostalgic 1970s amid the looks and songs of the period.

Sequined dresses, platform shoes, gold and platinum records everything is here, including the starry guitar Björn Ulvaeus played on April 6, 1974, the night ABBA won the Eurovision song contest with 'Waterloo'. As cultish as one of Jimi Hendrix's axes, this particular guitar was lost and then found in a garage in Germany. You might not be able to play on it, but you can pretend you're an ABBA member anyway. Try their hologram stage costumes, sing 'Mamma Mia', and leave with your own recorded interpretation! The ABBA museum adjoins the Swedish Music Hall of Fame museum, devoted to the pantheon of Swedish music of the 20th-century.

Those who visit it discover that Sweden exports as much music internationally as Ikea does furniture!

ABBA The Museum
Djurgårdsvägen 68
115 21 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 121 328 60

https://www.abbathemuseum.com

content.title: A Baltic Sea cruise

introduction.small: In the spring when the snows have melted, get on a steamboat and explore one or more of the 24,000 islands that make up the Stockholm archipelago.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Baltic Sea cruise

paragraphs.text:
Experience summer in Sweden by boarding a late afternoon ferry to Grinda for dinner.

Before sitting down in the restaurant to a freshly caught salmon, take a walk along the coast, and daydream about sleeping in one of those typical little red houses. These old one-room fisherman and farmer's huts have become getaway cottages for Stockholmers. Many are in their original state and have become inspirations for seaside decor. If you have more time, go for the day, and head for Finnhamn or Sandhamn. Stroll along the coast, dive off a cliff into the 20°C sea in August, dry yourself off and pick some blueberries. Have an afternoon nap in bright sunshine. But beware of sunburn, even in Sweden! Push on until Vaxholm. Vaxholm is a city spread out over 64 islands of which 16 are inhabited. Ideal for coastal shipping! And if, in the evening, you miss the ferry, go back by bus. In Stockholm, ferries dock at Nybrokajen and Strömkajen.

Tickets are sold at the pier, but in the summer, it is better to book your passage in advance and arrive a little early.

https://www.stromma.com/en-se/stockholm/

content.title: Scandic Grand Central: the ecological hotel

introduction.small: Imagine a 391-room hotel that operates 24/7 in green mode. Impossible? Not in Stockholm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Scandic Grand Central: the ecological hotel

paragraphs.text:
People from Malmo or Gothenburg love staying here because it is so conveniently located just minutes from the train and metro stations.

Scandic Grand Hotel also belongs to an ecological Scandinavian hotel chain. This is essential for Swedes! Four out of five Scandic hotels are labelled 'Swan', which is the Scandinavian eco-label. Energy reduction, water management, and recycling are all managed by the 'back office', but these things are appreciated as soon as you put down your luggage in any of the very comfortable rooms. The wooden floors are made from sustainably managed forests, and mattresses, pillows, and bed linen are 100% ecological, without synthetic or chemical materials.

Here, you need not worry about insomnia. Catch up on sleep and get over your jet-lag in a place where tranquillity, serenity, and calm reign on every floor.

Scandic Grand Central
Kungsgatan 70
111 20 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 517 350 00

https://www.scandichotels.com/grandcentral

Rooms: from 1,151 SEK

content.title: The Sturebadet Baths: a Nordic spa

introduction.small: You know about saunas and Swedish massages, but maybe not about Sami treatments, a wellness speciality of northern Sweden.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Sturebadet Baths: a Nordic spa

paragraphs.text:
Legend has it that Greta Garbo came here. Its Art Nouveau interior with a hint of Moorish influence goes against the current trend for stylish spas.

Created in 1885 by Carl Curman, a doctor who wanted to convert Stockholmers to holistic therapies for health and wellness, the Sturebadet baths have remained faithful to the spirit of their founder while offering novelties. Turkish baths, hydro massages and heated swimming pool are all available. Instead of saunas and the many varieties of Swedish massage, try the Sami treatment. Guests undress in a teepee, and alternate between exfoliation and a 39°C bath, followed by a long massage with essence of birch oil (since birch has detoxifying properties). For a romantic moment as a couple, some packages offer duo treatments.

Maybe feeling slaphappy at first, you will leave completely spruced up and full of incredible energy!

Sturebadet
Sturegallerian 36
114 46 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 545 015 00

https://sturebadet.se/en/

content.title: Miss Clara by Nobis: a Swedish boudoir

introduction.small: Is it because of its name? This hotel has a feminine je-ne-sais-quoi reflected in small subtle touches, all for the comfort of its residents.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Miss Clara by Nobis: a Swedish boudoir

paragraphs.text:
This used to be a boarding house for girls and has retained the name of its founder, Clara Stromberg. Everything is simple, clean, and full of charm, as if she were still watching over the well-being of her guests.

Its period architecture stylised Art Nouveau serves as a backdrop for contemporary Scandinavian furniture. The roundness of the style against the purity of the lines, the brown floors, the artwork lamps against the curtains, organic cotton bed linens these contrasts work together in bright, spacious rooms, inviting you to fall deliciously into slumber in Morpheus' arms.

However, you may also go to the window and watch the comings and goings of passers-by in this trendy area. Before going out, have a drink at the bar. The cocktails here are among the best in Stockholm. Furthermore, if you happen to be in the mood to party, the hotel houses crowd pleasing DJ sets every Friday.

Miss Clara by Nobis
Sveavägen 48
111 34 Stockholm

+46 (0)8 440 67 00

https://missclarahotel.com

Rooms: from 1,681 SEK
